awd_titl_txt: Advances in Bounded-Confidence Models on Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the broad usage of social media and the ease of sharing content, it is crucial to apply novel strategies to understand the underlying mechanisms of online content dissemination. The principal investigator and her team tackle this problem by studying a class of mathematical models of opinion dynamics called bounded-confidence models. These models provide an excellent framework because they are relatively simple models with surprisingly rich dynamics, and they are grounded in research from social science. The theoretical advances in the early stages of this project will in the final stages provide a strategy for fitting these models to real data, which is an important development that has so far gone largely unexplored. This work will contribute to the understanding of the mechanisms that shape information dissemination, including the spread of misinformation. In addition, this project supports extensive undergraduate student involvement and research training.

This research will be pursued from two complementary perspectives. First, using a combination of agent-based modeling and mean-field integro-differential equation models, the principal investigator and her team will study the effects of external forcing on networks where opinion states evolve via a synchronous-updating bounded-confidence mechanism. This allows for the characterization of the stationary states and bifurcations in the relevant order parameters. In parallel, the research team will study information cascades on networks using a novel twist on bounded-confidence mechanisms. The goal of this research is to provide insight into the study of competition, heterogeneity, and homophily on information dissemination and create a clear framework by which to compare these models with data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Due to the broad usage of social media and the ease of sharing content, it is crucial to apply novel strategies to understand the underlying mechanisms of online content dissemination. In this award, the PI and her team contributed toward this understanding through the study of a class of mechanistic models of opinion dynamics called bounded-confidence models. These models provide an excellent framework because they are relatively simple nonlinear models with surprisingly rich dynamics and they are grounded in research from social science. She and her team advanced the theory and application of bounded-confidence models on two complementary perspectives: (1) studying the eﬀects of external influencers on the opinion dynamics in a social network by creating analytically tractable network models, including a corresponding mean-field model, and (2) studying information cascades on networks using bounded-confidence mechanisms.

 

Intellectual Merit

The two aims described above represent an important contribution to the advancement of bounded-confidence models because they lead to important insights into potential mechanisms for polarization and content dissemination on social media. The first aim facilitates the characterizations of the stationary states and their relationship to initial conditions and external forcing. The PI and her team developed a new sigmoidal bounded-confidence model of opinion dynamics (SBCM). They show analytically that the stationary states (that is, the resulting opinion states) of the SBCM model behave like those in the well-studied linear averaging and Hegselmann–Krause models for sufficiently small and large values of a key parameter, respectively. Through this model, they are able to study the transition between these two regimes in certain graph topologies to characterize the stationary states, their stability, and their dependence on the model parameters. A key discovery and exciting result is that this model provides a framework to prove an interesting connection between community structure in networks and the stability of polarized stationary opinion states: opinion states that are aligned with community structure are stable for a wider range of parameter values than those that are misaligned with community structure. This contributes to the theoretical understanding of how structural connectivity (e.g., “echo chambers” in social media) is tied to polarized opinion states. 

 

The second aim involved the creation of a novel model of content dissemination based on a bounded-confidence

mechanism. The PI and her collaborators developed and analyzed an initial model for information cascades on networks via bounded-confidence mechanisms. This included defining an opinion reproduction number, which is an analogue of the basic reproduction number from disease dynamics. A critical value of the opinion reproduction number indicates whether or not there is an “infodemic” (i.e., a large content-spreading cascade) of content that reflects a particular opinion. By determining this critical value, one can determine whether or not an opinion dies off or propagates widely as a cascade in a population of agents. Using this model, it is possible to quantify the long-time effects of network size, connectivity, and model parameters on features of the resulting dissemination trees. Features studied include number of messages spread, width and diameter of the dissemination trees, and structural virality.

 

Broader Impacts

The spread of content online has important oﬄine impacts including inspiring protests, aﬀecting voting behavior, and influencing policy. This work has impacted the understanding of the ways in which polarization is potentially induced, exacerbated, or mitigated through media influence and interaction structure. Furthermore, it may contribute to the understanding of the mechanisms that shape information dissemination, including the spread of misinformation. 

 

This work provided meaningful student research activities at an undergraduate institution, supporting six undergraduate students in their professional development and preparation for the STEM workforce. The PI also worked with the student leadership team for the Women in Mathematics group at Harvey Mudd College to create a successful vertically-integrated mentorship network for students of underrepresented genders at Harvey Mudd College. This mentorship program has proved popular and includes both a student-student mentorship program, where junior and senior undergraduate students serve as mentors for freshman and sophomore mentees, and a student-alumni mentorship program for junior and senior undergraduate students.

 

Products resulting from this work are made publicly available as arXiv preprints and include reproducible code and simulation data through GitHub repositories. Finally, the project produced an accessible introductory tutorial on network science in social systems (arXiv preprint arXiv:2302.00801), as well as the development of a publicly-available set of lecture notes (Network Science: Models, Mathematics, and Computation: https://network-science-notes.github.io/).
